trans-unit.source: How to use the Azure Content Delivery Network portal advanced features - Azure feature guide
trans-unit.target: How to use the Azure Content Delivery Network portal advanced features - Azure feature guide

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the advanced features of the Azure portal to manage Content Delivery Network endpoints
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the advanced features of the Azure portal to manage Content Delivery Network endpoints

trans-unit.source: Azure Content Delivery Network portal user guide
trans-unit.target: Azure Content Delivery Network portal user guide

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: 中文版
trans-unit.target: 中文版

trans-unit.source: English Version
trans-unit.target: English Version

trans-unit.source: The Azure CDN caches static content in storage blobs, cloud services, and websites on the Azure platform by using large numbers of physical nodes distributed across Mainland China.
trans-unit.target: The Azure CDN caches static content in storage blobs, cloud services, and websites on the Azure platform by using large numbers of physical nodes distributed across Mainland China.

trans-unit.source: These nodes provide developers with a solution for delivering high-bandwidth content.
trans-unit.target: These nodes provide developers with a solution for delivering high-bandwidth content.

trans-unit.source: This service also currently supports the use of source stations that have not been deployed on the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: This service also currently supports the use of source stations that have not been deployed on the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: For more details and pricing for Content Delivery Network, see [Introduction to the Azure Content Delivery Network service](/home/features/cdn/).
trans-unit.target: For more details and pricing for Content Delivery Network, see [Introduction to the Azure Content Delivery Network service](/home/features/cdn/).

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Domain name management
trans-unit.target: Domain name management

trans-unit.target: Traffic reports

trans-unit.target: Bandwidth reports

trans-unit.target: Content prefetch

trans-unit.target: Service check

trans-unit.source: **Overview of the Azure CDN management portal**
trans-unit.target: **Overview of the Azure CDN management portal**

trans-unit.source: In Advance management page, you will see overview of then endpoints you created under selected subscription ID.
trans-unit.target: In Advance management page, you will see overview of then endpoints you created under selected subscription ID.

trans-unit.source: Parameters: Total Domain, Total Enabled Domain, Total Usage in Current Month and Bandwidths in Current Months.
trans-unit.target: Parameters: Total Domain, Total Enabled Domain, Total Usage in Current Month and Bandwidths in Current Months.

trans-unit.source: Total Domain
trans-unit.target: Total Domain

trans-unit.source: Total domains that were already created under the current Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Total domains that were already created under the current Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Total Enabled Domains
trans-unit.target: Total Enabled Domains

trans-unit.source: Statistics on accelerated domain names that are currently enabled under the current Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Statistics on accelerated domain names that are currently enabled under the current Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Total usage for the current month
trans-unit.target: Total usage for the current month

trans-unit.source: Total traffic in gigabytes (GB) that were used by all enabled domain names under the current Azure subscriptions during the current month.
trans-unit.target: Total traffic in gigabytes (GB) that were used by all enabled domain names under the current Azure subscriptions during the current month.

trans-unit.source: Usages in current month
trans-unit.target: Usages in current month

trans-unit.source: Details of traffic in GB for each day in the current month under the current Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Details of traffic in GB for each day in the current month under the current Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: If you need more detailed traffic information, you can click “Usage Chart” in the left navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: If you need more detailed traffic information, you can click “Usage Chart” in the left navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth in current month
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth in current month

trans-unit.source: Details of the peak bandwidth in megabytes per second (Mb/s) for each day in the current month.
trans-unit.target: Details of the peak bandwidth in megabytes per second (Mb/s) for each day in the current month.

trans-unit.source: If you need more detailed bandwidth information, click “Bandwidth Chart” in the left navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: If you need more detailed bandwidth information, click “Bandwidth Chart” in the left navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: **Domain name management**
trans-unit.target: **Domain name management**

trans-unit.source: Clicking “Domain Management” in the left navigation pane displays a list view of all domains that were created under the current Azure subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: Clicking “Domain Management” in the left navigation pane displays a list view of all domains that were created under the current Azure subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: You can select different subscriptions from the subscriptions drop-down list to see details of acceleration domain names under different subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: You can select different subscriptions from the subscriptions drop-down list to see details of acceleration domain names under different subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: You can perform operations like Modify Configurations, Configure Caching Rules and Access Control Management for selected domain.
trans-unit.target: You can perform operations like Modify Configurations, Configure Caching Rules and Access Control Management for selected domain.

trans-unit.source: Accelerated domain list view
trans-unit.target: Accelerated domain list view

trans-unit.source: The domain list view includes:
trans-unit.target: The domain list view includes:

trans-unit.source: Accelerated Domain, which are used to access CDN cached content.
trans-unit.target: Accelerated Domain, which are used to access CDN cached content.

trans-unit.source: These domains must be accompanied by the corresponding ICP record details.
trans-unit.target: These domains must be accompanied by the corresponding ICP record details.

trans-unit.source: CDN Domain, which are provided by the CDN platform and all end with **.mschcdn.com**.
trans-unit.target: CDN Domain, which are provided by the CDN platform and all end with **.mschcdn.com**.

trans-unit.source: Original Domain, which are the origin location for content cached on the CDN nodes.
trans-unit.target: Original Domain, which are the origin location for content cached on the CDN nodes.

trans-unit.source: Acceleration type, which includes the acceleration types that are currently supported: “website acceleration”, “download acceleration”, “HTTP VoD acceleration”, and “live streaming acceleration”.
trans-unit.target: Acceleration type, which includes the acceleration types that are currently supported: “website acceleration”, “download acceleration”, “HTTP VoD acceleration”, and “live streaming acceleration”.

trans-unit.source: Status, which may be either enabled or disabled (including verifying ICP, requires CNAME configuration, disabled).
trans-unit.target: Status, which may be either enabled or disabled (including verifying ICP, requires CNAME configuration, disabled).

trans-unit.source: **Note** that you need to CNAME your accelerated domain to CDN domain ending with **.mschcdn.com** provided by Azure CDN after the CDN service takes effect (within 60 minutes).
trans-unit.target: **Note** that you need to CNAME your accelerated domain to CDN domain ending with **.mschcdn.com** provided by Azure CDN after the CDN service takes effect (within 60 minutes).

trans-unit.source: **Note** that only domain names with an **enabled** status can use the CDN service.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that only domain names with an **enabled** status can use the CDN service.

trans-unit.source: Modify Configurations
trans-unit.target: Modify Configurations

trans-unit.source: You can modify Original domain and host header here.
trans-unit.target: You can modify Original domain and host header here.

trans-unit.source: Cache rule configuration
trans-unit.target: Cache rule configuration

trans-unit.source: Azure CDN has default caching rules.
trans-unit.target: Azure CDN has default caching rules.

trans-unit.source: You can also configure caching rules, which will be applied first.
trans-unit.target: You can also configure caching rules, which will be applied first.

trans-unit.source: If customized rules don't match, it will apply default caching rules.
trans-unit.target: If customized rules don't match, it will apply default caching rules.

trans-unit.source: You can click “Cache rule configuration” and then set cache rules for selected domain, including:
trans-unit.target: You can click “Cache rule configuration” and then set cache rules for selected domain, including:

trans-unit.source: Folder-based configuration.
trans-unit.target: Folder-based configuration.

trans-unit.source: Folders must begin with “/”, for example, /pic, /doc, or /htdoc/data.
trans-unit.target: Folders must begin with “/”, for example, /pic, /doc, or /htdoc/data.

trans-unit.source: The back end matches all files within the designated folders, **including subfolders**.
trans-unit.target: The back end matches all files within the designated folders, **including subfolders**.

trans-unit.source: File extension-based configuration.
trans-unit.target: File extension-based configuration.

trans-unit.source: The back end matches common file extensions, such as .jpg, .png, .gif, .txt, .m4v, or .mp3 **within all folders**.
trans-unit.target: The back end matches common file extensions, such as .jpg, .png, .gif, .txt, .m4v, or .mp3 **within all folders**.

trans-unit.source: Full path-based configuration
trans-unit.target: Full path-based configuration

trans-unit.source: These are used to specify **a single file**, and must start with a forward slash (/).
trans-unit.target: These are used to specify **a single file**, and must start with a forward slash (/).

trans-unit.source: For example, "/sites/doc/example.doc".
trans-unit.target: For example, "/sites/doc/example.doc".

trans-unit.source: **Note**: If the path entered by the user is “/”, it will match the homepage.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: If the path entered by the user is “/”, it will match the homepage.

trans-unit.source: **Note** that the character strings entered by the user when configuring rules must not include special characters such as “{”, “}”, “(”, “)”, “[”, “]”, “.”, “?”, “*”, “\\”, “^”, or “$”.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that the character strings entered by the user when configuring rules must not include special characters such as “{”, “}”, “(”, “)”, “[”, “]”, “.”, “?”, “*”, “\\”, “^”, or “$”.

trans-unit.source: **Note** that entering a time of “0” means that caching is prohibited.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that entering a time of “0” means that caching is prohibited.

trans-unit.source: Cache rules order
trans-unit.target: Cache rules order

trans-unit.source: The system match cache rules on the basis of the order of configuration, with the rule configured first given the highest priority level.
trans-unit.target: The system match cache rules on the basis of the order of configuration, with the rule configured first given the highest priority level.

trans-unit.source: Once a rule is matched, subsequent rules are **no longer** matched.
trans-unit.target: Once a rule is matched, subsequent rules are **no longer** matched.

trans-unit.source: Pre-defined templates
trans-unit.target: Pre-defined templates

trans-unit.source: Users can use “Apply pre-defined template” to quickly create cache configuration rules.
trans-unit.target: Users can use “Apply pre-defined template” to quickly create cache configuration rules.

trans-unit.source: As forbidden
trans-unit.target: As forbidden

trans-unit.source: If the user checks the “As forbidden” option, the accelerated domain name is not cached.
trans-unit.target: If the user checks the “As forbidden” option, the accelerated domain name is not cached.

trans-unit.source: Access control management
trans-unit.target: Access control management

trans-unit.source: You can use access control management to set up and configure referer blacklists and whitelists, and thereby implement an anti-theft chain.
trans-unit.target: You can use access control management to set up and configure referer blacklists and whitelists, and thereby implement an anti-theft chain.

trans-unit.source: Once the anti theft chain is enabled, you can edit the external link rules.
trans-unit.target: Once the anti theft chain is enabled, you can edit the external link rules.

trans-unit.source: Each rule is made up of a path and a filename, for example, / *.png means all png files in the root directory.
trans-unit.target: Each rule is made up of a path and a filename, for example, / *.png means all png files in the root directory.

trans-unit.source: Each rule is made up of a path and a filename, for example, / *.png means all png files in the root directory.
trans-unit.target: Each rule is made up of a path and a filename, for example, / *.png means all png files in the root directory.

trans-unit.source: If you set up a blacklist, access is denied if the referer is in the blacklist, but is otherwise permitted.
trans-unit.target: If you set up a blacklist, access is denied if the referer is in the blacklist, but is otherwise permitted.

trans-unit.source: If you set up a whitelist, access is permitted only if the referer is one of the domain names in the whitelist.
trans-unit.target: If you set up a whitelist, access is permitted only if the referer is one of the domain names in the whitelist.

trans-unit.source: Once you have clicked “Submit” and waited for the operation to finish, the interface shows whether the operation was successful.
trans-unit.target: Once you have clicked “Submit” and waited for the operation to finish, the interface shows whether the operation was successful.

trans-unit.source: If you click “Submit and close”, then the dialog box closes immediately.
trans-unit.target: If you click “Submit and close”, then the dialog box closes immediately.

trans-unit.source: The next time you open the dialog box, you see the status of the last operation.
trans-unit.target: The next time you open the dialog box, you see the status of the last operation.

trans-unit.source: **Usage Chart**
trans-unit.target: **Usage Chart**

trans-unit.source: Select the subscription (choose one), time range, and accelerated domain(individual domain names or all of them) you wish to check, then click **Refresh**.
trans-unit.target: Select the subscription (choose one), time range, and accelerated domain(individual domain names or all of them) you wish to check, then click **Refresh**.

trans-unit.source: The interface displays usage chart that meet the conditions you specified.
trans-unit.target: The interface displays usage chart that meet the conditions you specified.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.

trans-unit.source: Usage chart has the following functions:
trans-unit.target: Usage chart has the following functions:

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can check usage chart for individual subscriptions, as well as return-to-source usage.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can check usage chart for individual subscriptions, as well as return-to-source usage.

trans-unit.source: If you have Azure subscriptions with multiple accelerated domains, you can view individual accelerated domain name traffic (and return-to-source traffic) and summaries of all accelerated domains traffic (and return-to-source traffic).
trans-unit.target: If you have Azure subscriptions with multiple accelerated domains, you can view individual accelerated domain name traffic (and return-to-source traffic) and summaries of all accelerated domains traffic (and return-to-source traffic).

trans-unit.source: Granularity for usage is up to hour.
trans-unit.target: Granularity for usage is up to hour.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple time range types to check usage, including the last 24 hours, yesterday, today, the last 7 days, the last 15 days, the last 30 days, or the last month.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple time range types to check usage, including the last 24 hours, yesterday, today, the last 7 days, the last 15 days, the last 30 days, or the last month.

trans-unit.source: You can also check traffic and return-to-source traffic for a specific time period, which cannot exceed 90 days.
trans-unit.target: You can also check traffic and return-to-source traffic for a specific time period, which cannot exceed 90 days.

trans-unit.source: **Bandwidth chart**
trans-unit.target: **Bandwidth chart**

trans-unit.source: Select the subscription (choose one), time range, and accelerated domains (individual domain names or all of them) you wish to check, then click **Refresh**.
trans-unit.target: Select the subscription (choose one), time range, and accelerated domains (individual domain names or all of them) you wish to check, then click **Refresh**.

trans-unit.source: The interface displays bandwidth charts that meet the conditions you specified.
trans-unit.target: The interface displays bandwidth charts that meet the conditions you specified.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth chart has the following functions:
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth chart has the following functions:

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can check bandwidth chart for individual subscriptions, as well as return-to-source bandwidth.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can check bandwidth chart for individual subscriptions, as well as return-to-source bandwidth.

trans-unit.source: If you have Azure subscriptions with multiple accelerated domain names, you can view individual accelerated domain bandwidth (and return-to-source traffic) and summaries of all accelerated domain bandwidth (and return-to-source traffic) information.
trans-unit.target: If you have Azure subscriptions with multiple accelerated domain names, you can view individual accelerated domain bandwidth (and return-to-source traffic) and summaries of all accelerated domain bandwidth (and return-to-source traffic) information.

trans-unit.source: Granularity for usage is up to hour.
trans-unit.target: Granularity for usage is up to hour.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple time range types to check bandwidth, including the last 24 hours, yesterday, today, the last 7 days, the last 15 days, the last 30 days, or the last month.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple time range types to check bandwidth, including the last 24 hours, yesterday, today, the last 7 days, the last 15 days, the last 30 days, or the last month.

trans-unit.source: You can also check bandwidth and return-to-source bandwidt for a specific time period, which cannot exceed 90 days.
trans-unit.target: You can also check bandwidth and return-to-source bandwidt for a specific time period, which cannot exceed 90 days.

trans-unit.source: Bandwidth chart displays the time at which peak bandwidth levels occur.
trans-unit.target: Bandwidth chart displays the time at which peak bandwidth levels occur.

trans-unit.source: **Cache refresh**
trans-unit.target: **Cache refresh**

trans-unit.source: Clicking “Cache Refresh” in the bottom-left navigation pane performs a manual refresh of the specified files or folders.
trans-unit.target: Clicking “Cache Refresh” in the bottom-left navigation pane performs a manual refresh of the specified files or folders.

trans-unit.source: Cache refresh list view
trans-unit.target: Cache refresh list view

trans-unit.source: Select the subscription (choose one), status, time range, and accelerated domains (choose one) you wish to check.
trans-unit.target: Select the subscription (choose one), status, time range, and accelerated domains (choose one) you wish to check.

trans-unit.source: The interface displays cache refresh records that meet the conditions you specified.
trans-unit.target: The interface displays cache refresh records that meet the conditions you specified.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.

trans-unit.source: Cache refresh list view includes:
trans-unit.target: Cache refresh list view includes:

trans-unit.source: Accelerated domain names, which are URLs that are used to access CDN cache content.
trans-unit.target: Accelerated domain names, which are URLs that are used to access CDN cache content.

trans-unit.source: Status (common statuses: successful, failed, or refreshing)
trans-unit.target: Status (common statuses: successful, failed, or refreshing)

trans-unit.source: Submit time
trans-unit.target: Submit time

trans-unit.source: Check time
trans-unit.target: Check time

trans-unit.source: If you successfully submitted the cache refresh rules, the status column shows the word “Successful”.
trans-unit.target: If you successfully submitted the cache refresh rules, the status column shows the word “Successful”.

trans-unit.source: If you did not successfully submit them, you must check that the cache refresh rules were correct.
trans-unit.target: If you did not successfully submit them, you must check that the cache refresh rules were correct.

trans-unit.source: If there are any problems, you must re-create and re-submit the cache refresh rules.
trans-unit.target: If there are any problems, you must re-create and re-submit the cache refresh rules.

trans-unit.source: Configure cache refresh rules
trans-unit.target: Configure cache refresh rules

trans-unit.source: You can configure cache refresh rules for individual files or for all files within a folder.
trans-unit.target: You can configure cache refresh rules for individual files or for all files within a folder.

trans-unit.source: Submit File Refresh
trans-unit.target: Submit File Refresh

trans-unit.source: This task includes the steps listed below:
trans-unit.target: This task includes the steps listed below:

trans-unit.source: Click “Submit File Refresh” to enter the file refresh view.
trans-unit.target: Click “Submit File Refresh” to enter the file refresh view.

trans-unit.source: In the “File Refreshing” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding file path.
trans-unit.target: In the “File Refreshing” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding file path.

trans-unit.source: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding file.
trans-unit.target: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding file.

trans-unit.source: Click “Submit”.
trans-unit.target: Click “Submit”.

trans-unit.source: The newly created file cache rules then appear in the cache refresh list view.
trans-unit.target: The newly created file cache rules then appear in the cache refresh list view.

trans-unit.source: **Note** that until the accelerated domain has passed the ICP verification process, it is not possible to perform a file refresh operation and the accelerated domain name drop-down list appears empty.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that until the accelerated domain has passed the ICP verification process, it is not possible to perform a file refresh operation and the accelerated domain name drop-down list appears empty.

trans-unit.source: Wait until it has passed ICP verification.
trans-unit.target: Wait until it has passed ICP verification.

trans-unit.source: Submit folder refresh
trans-unit.target: Submit folder refresh

trans-unit.source: This task includes the steps listed below:
trans-unit.target: This task includes the steps listed below:

trans-unit.source: click “Submit Folder Refresh” to enter the folder refreshing view.
trans-unit.target: click “Submit Folder Refresh” to enter the folder refreshing view.

trans-unit.source: In the “Folder Refreshing” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding folder path.
trans-unit.target: In the “Folder Refreshing” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding folder path.

trans-unit.source: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding directory.
trans-unit.target: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding directory.

trans-unit.source: Click “Submit”.
trans-unit.target: Click “Submit”.

trans-unit.source: The newly created folder cache rules then appear in the cache refresh list view.
trans-unit.target: The newly created folder cache rules then appear in the cache refresh list view.

trans-unit.source: **Content prefetch**
trans-unit.target: **Content prefetch**

trans-unit.source: Click “Content Prefetch” in the left navigation pane to perform content prefetch operations and check prefetch status for specific files.
trans-unit.target: Click “Content Prefetch” in the left navigation pane to perform content prefetch operations and check prefetch status for specific files.

trans-unit.source: Content prefetch means caching the content of a designated URL from the source station to the CDN nodes.
trans-unit.target: Content prefetch means caching the content of a designated URL from the source station to the CDN nodes.

trans-unit.source: This eliminates the waiting time the first time that you access the resource.
trans-unit.target: This eliminates the waiting time the first time that you access the resource.

trans-unit.source: Content prefetching is generally used in scenarios that involve the delivery of large files, where it can effectively improve the user access experience.
trans-unit.target: Content prefetching is generally used in scenarios that involve the delivery of large files, where it can effectively improve the user access experience.

trans-unit.source: Content prefetch list view
trans-unit.target: Content prefetch list view

trans-unit.source: Select the subscription (choose one), status, time range, and accelerated domain (choose one) you wish to check.
trans-unit.target: Select the subscription (choose one), status, time range, and accelerated domain (choose one) you wish to check.

trans-unit.source: The interface displays precaching records that meet the conditions you specified.
trans-unit.target: The interface displays precaching records that meet the conditions you specified.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the explanations on the actual interface page for data format details and implications.

trans-unit.source: The content prefetch list view includes:
trans-unit.target: The content prefetch list view includes:

trans-unit.source: Accelerated domain, which are URLs that are used to access CDN cache content.
trans-unit.target: Accelerated domain, which are URLs that are used to access CDN cache content.

trans-unit.source: Status (common statuses: successful, failed, or in progress)
trans-unit.target: Status (common statuses: successful, failed, or in progress)

trans-unit.source: Submit time
trans-unit.target: Submit time

trans-unit.source: If you successfully submitted the precache rules, the status column shows the word “Successful”.
trans-unit.target: If you successfully submitted the precache rules, the status column shows the word “Successful”.

trans-unit.source: If you did not successfully submit them, you must check that the precache rules were correct.
trans-unit.target: If you did not successfully submit them, you must check that the precache rules were correct.

trans-unit.source: If there are any problems, you must re-create and re-submit the precache rules.
trans-unit.target: If there are any problems, you must re-create and re-submit the precache rules.

trans-unit.source: Submit Precache
trans-unit.target: Submit Precache

trans-unit.source: You can configure precaching for individual files or multiple files.
trans-unit.target: You can configure precaching for individual files or multiple files.

trans-unit.source: This task includes the steps listed below:
trans-unit.target: This task includes the steps listed below:

trans-unit.source: Click on “Submit Prefetch”.
trans-unit.target: Click on “Submit Prefetch”.

trans-unit.source: In the “Content Prefetch” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding file path.
trans-unit.target: In the “Content Prefetch” dialog box, select the domain you wish to configure, and then enter the corresponding file path.

trans-unit.source: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding file.
trans-unit.target: Click “+” to add a new rule or “x” to delete the corresponding file.

trans-unit.source: Click “Submit”.
trans-unit.target: Click “Submit”.

trans-unit.source: The newly created prefetch rules then appear in the Content Prefetch list view.
trans-unit.target: The newly created prefetch rules then appear in the Content Prefetch list view.

trans-unit.source: **Log download**
trans-unit.target: **Log download**

trans-unit.source: Click “Log Download” in the left navigation pane to set CDN log download parameters for specific domains.
trans-unit.target: Click “Log Download” in the left navigation pane to set CDN log download parameters for specific domains.

trans-unit.source: Log download view
trans-unit.target: Log download view

trans-unit.source: To download logs, you must first provide an Azure storage account that is used to save CDN logs.
trans-unit.target: To download logs, you must first provide an Azure storage account that is used to save CDN logs.

trans-unit.source: Click “Download Settings” to set this up.
trans-unit.target: Click “Download Settings” to set this up.

trans-unit.source: Download settings view
trans-unit.target: Download settings view

trans-unit.source: You can set the storage account and the domain names for which log downloads are required in the “Download Settings” view.
trans-unit.target: You can set the storage account and the domain names for which log downloads are required in the “Download Settings” view.

trans-unit.source: Once the setup is complete, the system automatically saves the logs that it finds to the designated storage account.
trans-unit.target: Once the setup is complete, the system automatically saves the logs that it finds to the designated storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can delete the storage account to cancel log downloads.
trans-unit.target: You can delete the storage account to cancel log downloads.

trans-unit.source: Log format details
trans-unit.target: Log format details

trans-unit.source: Logs are saved in blob format with a container called "cdn-access-logs".
trans-unit.target: Logs are saved in blob format with a container called "cdn-access-logs".

trans-unit.source: Every blob consists of a .csv file that is compressed with GZip.
trans-unit.target: Every blob consists of a .csv file that is compressed with GZip.

trans-unit.source: The meaning of each column within the log is given below:
trans-unit.target: The meaning of each column within the log is given below:

trans-unit.source: c-ip: Client IP address
trans-unit.target: c-ip: Client IP address

trans-unit.source: timestamp: Access time
trans-unit.target: timestamp: Access time

trans-unit.source: cs-method: HTTP request actions, such as GET/HEAD
trans-unit.target: cs-method: HTTP request actions, such as GET/HEAD

trans-unit.source: cs-uri-stem: Requested URI
trans-unit.target: cs-uri-stem: Requested URI

trans-unit.source: http-ver: HTTP protocol version number
trans-unit.target: http-ver: HTTP protocol version number

trans-unit.source: sc-status: HTTP status code
trans-unit.target: sc-status: HTTP status code

trans-unit.source: sc-bytes: Number of bytes sent to the client by the server
trans-unit.target: sc-bytes: Number of bytes sent to the client by the server

trans-unit.source: c-referer: Client-side referer URI
trans-unit.target: c-referer: Client-side referer URI

trans-unit.source: c-user-agent: Client user agent identification
trans-unit.target: c-user-agent: Client user agent identification

trans-unit.source: rs-duration (ms): Time taken to complete the request (in milliseconds)
trans-unit.target: rs-duration (ms): Time taken to complete the request (in milliseconds)

trans-unit.source: hit-miss: Content Delivery Network cache hit and miss identification
trans-unit.target: hit-miss: Content Delivery Network cache hit and miss identification

trans-unit.source: s-ip: IP address of the Content Delivery Network edge node that generated the log
trans-unit.target: s-ip: IP address of the Content Delivery Network edge node that generated the log

trans-unit.source: **Note** that if the CDN log does not contain content for a particular column, the corresponding record, for example the “c-referer” record, will be marked “-”.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that if the CDN log does not contain content for a particular column, the corresponding record, for example the “c-referer” record, will be marked “-”.

trans-unit.source: Also, depending on the edge node log configuration, the “rs-duration”, “hit-miss” and “s-ip” columns may also be empty.
trans-unit.target: Also, depending on the edge node log configuration, the “rs-duration”, “hit-miss” and “s-ip” columns may also be empty.

trans-unit.source: **Note** that once a website has been accelerated by CDN, the majority of its access records come from CDN edge nodes.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that once a website has been accelerated by CDN, the majority of its access records come from CDN edge nodes.

trans-unit.source: When the network returns to the source, it enters the originating IP address in HTTP Header X-Forwarded-For, and the source station’s web server can edit the log to configure this information.
trans-unit.target: When the network returns to the source, it enters the originating IP address in HTTP Header X-Forwarded-For, and the source station’s web server can edit the log to configure this information.

trans-unit.source: If you need to find out the originating IP address of the client, you can refer to the information below.
trans-unit.target: If you need to find out the originating IP address of the client, you can refer to the information below.

trans-unit.source: If we take NGINX as an example, you can add the following information to the configuration file:
trans-unit.target: If we take NGINX as an example, you can add the following information to the configuration file:

trans-unit.source: log\_format logCDN '$remote\_addr forwarded for $http\_x\_forwarded\_for - $remote\_user [$time\_local] ' '"$request" $status $body\_bytes\_sent ' '"$http\_referer" "$http\_user\_agent"';
trans-unit.target: log\_format logCDN '$remote\_addr forwarded for $http\_x\_forwarded\_for - $remote\_user [$time\_local] ' '"$request" $status $body\_bytes\_sent ' '"$http\_referer" "$http\_user\_agent"';

trans-unit.source: access\_log /var/log/nginx/access.log logCDN;
trans-unit.target: access\_log /var/log/nginx/access.log logCDN;

trans-unit.source: **Service check**
trans-unit.target: **Service check**

trans-unit.source: Once you have created a CDN endpoint, you can perform some basic checks in the “Service Check” view.
trans-unit.target: Once you have created a CDN endpoint, you can perform some basic checks in the “Service Check” view.

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend that you perform service checks before you carry out CNAME operations.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend that you perform service checks before you carry out CNAME operations.

trans-unit.source: As shown in the view above, you must select the domain name to be checked, provide a resource that the source station can access, and then click “Check”.
trans-unit.target: As shown in the view above, you must select the domain name to be checked, provide a resource that the source station can access, and then click “Check”.

trans-unit.source: he original domain is OK (HTTP status code is 200) - means the domain works
trans-unit.target: he original domain is OK (HTTP status code is 200) - means the domain works

trans-unit.source: CDN service is deployed - means the CDN service is deployed
trans-unit.target: CDN service is deployed - means the CDN service is deployed

trans-unit.source: The CDN cache is OK - means the contents accessed from both origin and CDN endpoints are the same (by HTTP host header：HTTP Status Code，Last Modified Time，Content Length).
trans-unit.target: The CDN cache is OK - means the contents accessed from both origin and CDN endpoints are the same (by HTTP host header：HTTP Status Code，Last Modified Time，Content Length).

trans-unit.source: **Note** that using the service check function does not guarantee that there are no anomalies in any of the CDN edge servers where the domain is located.
trans-unit.target: **Note** that using the service check function does not guarantee that there are no anomalies in any of the CDN edge servers where the domain is located.
